choices.text: It represents persistence of an embryonic communication between roof of primitive pharynx and the notochord
It's management includes marsupialization or excision
It is a collection of lymphoid tissue
It extends from mucosa of nasopharynx to occiput

questions.text: A patient presented with complain of persistent post nasal drip, occipital headache. Nasal endoscopy was done which showed presence of a blind and inflamed sac in the nasopharynx in the midline. Picture given below. Which of the following is false about the condition?
questions.solution:
Based on clinical features and picture the diagnosis in this case is Thornwaldt bursitis.

Thornwaldt bursitis is a nasopharyngeal cyst and not a collection of lymphoid tissue. ( Option C ) The Main differential diagnosis in this case is adenoid hypertrophy.

Thornwaldt bursa lies in the midline at junction of roof and posterior wall of the nasopharynx.

Adenoid hypertrophy are also extended to lateral wall of nasopharynx and adenoid have vertical ridges on the surface.

Thornwaldt bursa is a persistence of an embryonic communication between the roof of primitive pharynx and the notochord. ( Option A ).

It extends from mucosa of nasopharynx to occiput. ( Option D )

It presents as persistent post nasal drip, occipital headache, and sore throat and fever.

Its treatment includes antibiotics and if cyst or abscess formation occurs then excision or marsupialization. ( Option B )

Key Takeaway :

Thornwaldt bursitis :

  • Nasopharyngeal cyst from Roof of nasopharynx to occiput.
  • O/E - Post Nasal Drip, Occipital headache
  • Mx - Excision / Marsupialization if Infected

Image reference: Medtube website.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with complain of swelling over left side of neck. Biopsy of the swelling revealed well differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. The patient also developed pain in the lower jaw, conductive type of deafness and palatal palsy. What is the most probable diagnosis based on it ?
questions.solution:
The most common presentation of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is unilateral neck swelling.

Neoplastic infiltration of sinus of Morgagni can lead to the development of ipsilateral conductive hearing loss, ipsilateral trigeminal neuralgia and ipsilateral soft palate palsy. This is known as Trotter's triad.

Conductive deafness develops due to compression of Eustachian tube.

Palatal palsy occurs secondary to the akinesia of Levator veli palatini.

Trigeminal neuralgia occurs due to close proximity of sinus of Morgagni to the foramen ovale.

Mnemonic Nasopharyngeal carcinoma NPC -Neuralgia of ipsilateral head, palatal palsy, Conductive hearing loss.

Option A: Juvenile Angiofibroma present in young male patient with recurrent epistaxis.

Option B: Acoustic Neuroma Present with Tinnitus with UL SNHL in elderly Patients.

Option D: Glomus Tumor Present with Pulsatile Tinnitus with CHL.

Key Takeaway:

Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma MC presentation - UL Deep Cervical Lymphadenopathy. If it Involves Sinus of Morgagni - Trotter triad of Neuralgia, Palatal Palsy & CHL occurs.

choices.text: Passavant's ridge is formed by stylopharyngeus
Lower border of nasopharynx corresponds to facial pillar
It lies opposite to 3rd cervical vertebra
Fossa of Rosenmuller corresponds to internal carotid artery

questions.text: Which of the following statements in context to anatomy of the nasopharynx is true?
questions.solution:
Nasopharynx is the upper most part of pharynx lying posterior to the nasal cavity. It lies above the oropharynx hence called epipharynx.

It extends from the base of skull above to the soft palate below. ( Option B ) It lies opposite to the 1st cervical vertebra. ( Option C ) Passavant's ridge is formed by palatopharyngeus. ( Option A )

Fossa of Rosenmuller lies in the lateral wall of nasopharynx. Lateral to the lateral pharyngeal wall of nasopharynx and oropharynx in the parapharyngeal space through which the internal carotid artery passes. ( Option D )

The posterior wall of nasopharynx shows the collection of lymphoid tissues known as adenoids. The lateral wall of nasopharynx is the posterior continuation of the lateral wall of nose.

The lateral wall of nasopharynx contains opening of Eustachian tube 1.25 cm behind the posterior end of inferior turbinate. The cartilage of Eustachian tube presents as a bulge known as torus tubarius.

Behind and above the torus tubarius there is a depression/Fossa, also known as fossa of Rosenmuller. This is the most common site of origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

Key Takeaway:

Nasopharynx

  • Lateral Wall - Torus Tubarius & Fossa of Rosenmuller
  • Extend From Occiput to First two cervical vertebrae
  • Posterior wall - Passavant's ridge by Palatopharyngeus.

choices.text: Recurrent upper respiratory tract infection and sinusitis
Recurrent middle ear infection with deafness

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with complain of recurrent URTI with mouth breathing and snoring. His x-ray nose lateral view is given below. He was advised adenoidectomy. This child should be advised for adenoidectomy if all of the following are present except?
questions.solution:
Adenoids are the aggregation of lymphoid tissue present in the nasopharynx.

Clinical features of hypertrophied adenoids include mouth breathing, adenoid facies, Recurrent sinusitis, URTI, Recurrent AOM and SOM, Sleep apnoea and Rhinolalia clausa or Hypo nasality.

Investigations: nasal endoscopy and Xray nose lateral view.

Indications of adenoidectomy includes:

Recurrent URTI, sinusitis, AOM and SOM, Sleep apnoea, and Hypo nasality. ( Option A , B & C )

Contraindications of surgery: Bleeding disorders and velopharyngeal insufficiency.

Key Takeaway:

Indication of adenoidectomy :

  • Recurrent URTI / Sinusitis
  • AOM & SOM
  • Sleep Apnea & Hyponasality

Image reference: Radiopedia.

choices.text: It is always a cellulitis and not an abscess
It involves the submandibular and sublingual glands
It spreads through tissue spaces and not through lymphatic

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presented with complain of pain and swelling over floor of mouth, bilateral submandibular region. The entire region was tender and inflamed. Patient gave a past history of tooth extraction. Patient also has uncontrolled diabetes. Picture given below. All of the following are diagnostic criteria for this condition except?
questions.solution:
In the above condition, the swelling involves bilateral submandibular region. It developed following dental extraction.

Patient also has uncontrolled diabetes. It involves floor of mouth. All these points lead to diagnosis of Ludwig's abscess.

There are four Goldring's criteria to diagnose Ludwig's abscess.

  • It is always cellulitis and not an abscess. If an abscess is present it is known as submandibular abscess and not Ludwig's angina. ( Option A )
  • It is always bilateral ( Option B )
  • It spreads through tissue space and not through lymphatic. ( Option D )
  • It does not involve the submandibular and sublingual glands. ( Option C )

Management: Incision and drainage A horizontal incision is kept 2 to 3 cm below the lower border of mandible extending from angle of mandible to the other.

Antibiotics covering both aerobes and anaerobes.

Key Takeaway:

Ludwig's Angina:

  • Bilateral Cellulitis which spread through tissue space without involving salivary glands.

Image reference: Downeast emergency medicine website.

questions.text: 30-year-old male patient underwent tooth extraction. Now he presents with fever and trismus. Examination reveals that the tonsils are pushed medially. There is also swelling on the neck at upper border of sternocleidomastoid. Trismus in this case is due to which muscle?
questions.solution:
Trismus is the inability to open the mouth due to spasm of muscles of mastication.

Based on the clinical features, the diagnosis in this case is Parapharyngeal abscess.

Trismus can develop due to all of the muscles mentioned in the above options. That is medial and lateral pterygoid, masseter and temporalis.

In parapharyngeal space abscess, trismus is mainly because of spasm of medial pterygoid. Medial pterygoid muscle lies just opposite to the parapharyngeal space laterally. It being attached to the medial aspect of mandible. ( Option A , B & D )

Key Takeaway:

In parapharyngeal space abscess, trismus is mainly because of spasm of medial pterygoid due to close anatomical proximation.

Image reference: emdocs.net

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient known case of fracture of maxilla was undertaken for reduction through Caldwell luc approach. Picture Is given below. What is the most common complication of Caldwell Luc approach?
questions.solution:
Caldwell luc operation is the procedure of opening the maxillary antrum by making an opening on its anterior wall by giving a sub labial incision.

With advent of FESS it is no longer done for chronic maxillary sinusitis and AC polyp. It's present indications are:

  • Reduction of maxillary fractures
  • Elevation of fracture of floor of orbit in blow out fracture.
  • Opening of posterior wall of maxillary sinus for approaching sphenopalatine fossa.
  • Taking a biopsy in suspected malignancy of maxilla.

It's complications are:

  • Anaesthesia or paraesthesia of the cheek, teeth and gingiva because of stretch injury of infraorbital nerve.
  • Trauma to tooth
  • Oro antral fistula
  • Haemorrhage
  • Injury to orbit

Options A, C & D:

Although all listed complications occur but infraorbital nerve injury is most common.

Key Takeaway:

Most Common Complication of Caldwell luc operation is infraorbital nerve injury which present with anaesthesia of cheek, teeth & gingiva.

Image reference: Research gate.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male patient known case of angiofibroma, his CT Scan was performed. His CT Scan showed tumour extending in the nasal cavity, maxillary sinus, it also fills the sphenopalatine fossa and extending into infratemporal fossa. CT scan picture is given below. What will be the stage of this tumour as per the Sessions staging system?
questions.solution:
According to the Sessions staging system

Key Takeaway :

According to session staging, When Angiofibroma involves infratemporal fossa it's stage 2c.

Image reference: Radiopedia.

questions.text: A 8-year-old male patient underwent tonsillectomy. Patient developed bleeding from the tonsillar fossa 6 days after the surgery. Which of the following can lead to such bleeding after tonsillectomy?
questions.solution:
The most common complication after tonsillectomy is Haemorrhage.

Haemorrhage during / following tonsillectomy is of 3 types.

  • Primary Haemorrhage: This is Haemorrhage occurring during the surgery secondary to injury to blood vessels while operating. ( Option A )
  • Reactionary Haemorrhage: This occurs after surgery to within 24 hours. This occurs because of lodgement of clot or slippage of ligature because of the blood pressure coming back to normal after surgery. ( Option C ) The patient is anesthetized and Haemorrhage is managed by re exploration.
  • Secondary Haemorrhage: This occurs between 24 hrs to 10 days, most commonly 5 to 8 days. This occurs due to Secondary to infection. The patient is started on iv antibiotics first and if not controlled, he is anaesthetised and managed.

The Haemorrhage developed in this case is secondary type which develops due to Secondary infection, which develops due to patient not taking antibiotics. ( Option B )

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: A 7-year-old male patient presented with complain of repeated throat infection since 3 years. On examination his oropharynx showed enlarged bilateral tonsils. Picture given below. All are the following are the contraindications of tonsillectomy except?
questions.solution:
Contraindications of tonsillectomy includes:

  • Bleeding disorders ( Option A )
  • Polio epidemic: since the polio virus gets concentrated in the lymphoid tissues of the tonsils and adenoids, tonsillectomy can lead to entry of virus into the bloodstream, triggering paralytic polio. ( Option B )
  • Cleft lip and palate: They are relative contraindications as these patients are at risk for velopharyngeal insufficiency getting unmasked post surgery. ( Option C )
  • Acute upper respiratory tract infection and tonsillitis: chances of Haemorrhage and septicemia is high. Surgery is postponed for three weeks.

Key Takeaway:

Tonsillectomy Contraindications : ABC

  • Acute URTI
  • Bleeding Disorder
  • Cleft lip & Palate
  • Polio Epidemic

Image reference: Science photo library.

questions.text: An 8-year-old male patient presented with complain of severe throat pain, fever and odynophagia. His voice is muffled (hot potato voice). On examination tonsil and uvula is pushed towards opposite side. Picture given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hot potato voice and shifting of uvula to the opposite side are characteristic of peritonsillar abscess.

Option A : Abscess in retropharyngeal space : Inflammation of nodes of Rouviere → O/E : U/l bulge of posterior pharyngeal wall.

Option C : Abscess in prevertebral space : Midline diffuse bulge of posterior pharyngeal wall.

Key Takeaway :

Hot potato voice and shifting of uvula to the opposite side are characteristic of peritonsillar abscess.

Image reference: wikipedia

questions.text: A 30-year-old male underwent tooth extraction for dental caries. Now he presents with fever and trismus. Oropharyngeal examination is revealing that the tonsils are pushed medially. There is also swelling in the upper border of sternocleidomastoid muscle. Most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical picture and symptoms, the diagnosis in this case is Parapharyngeal abscess.

It is an abscess present just lateral to lateral pharyngeal wall.

It is the most commonly infected space of pharynx as infection from tonsil, dental, parotid, retropharyngeal and submandibular space.

Clinical features: Tonsils pushed medially, Trismus due to spasm of medial pterygoid muscle.

Bulge in the neck at the angle of jaw, bulge in the neck at the angle of jaw at upper 1/3rd of sternocleidomastoid muscle.

Management: A horizontal incision is kept 2 to 3 cm below the lower border of the mandible, along with IV antibiotics.

Option A: Abscess in retropharyngeal space: Inflammation of nodes of Rouvier → O/E: U/l bulge of posterior pharyngeal wall.

Option C: Ludwig angina present with bilateral woody edema below mandible with raised floor of mouth.

Option D: Hot potato voice and shifting of uvula to the opposite side are characteristic of peritonsillar abscess.

Key Takeaway:

Parapharyngeal abscess Presentation:

  • Tonsil Pushed medially
  • Trismus due to Medial Pterygoid
  • External Swelling in neck at upper 1/3rd of SCM.

Image reference: Radiopedia.

choices.text: St Clair Thompson adenoid curette with cage

questions.text: What is the name of the instrument given in the picture below?
questions.solution:
Tonsil holding forceps are long with Shaft Bent at an angle to the handle. The tips are cup shaped with holes. The edges of the tip are smooth just to hold the tissue without cutting it. It is used in tonsillectomy.

Option B : St Clair Thompson adenoid curettage with cage has a strong handle, a shaft and a curettage at the tip. The curate is curved, square window that allows adenoid tissue to engage.

Option C : Luc's forceps To differentiate this instrument from tonsil holding forceps the tip of the LUC's forceps are sharper because they have to do some cutting. Also the cup shaped tip of the upper arm fits into the tip of lower arm in tonsil holding forceps whereas in luc's forceps they approximate each other.

Option D : Straight Blakesley ethmoidectomy forceps are similar to Luc's forceps but have a longer Shaft and smoother tip edge.

Key Takeaway :

Tonsil holding forceps are long with Shaft Bent at an angle to the handle. The tips are cup shaped with holes. The edges of the tip are smooth just to hold the tissue without cutting it. It is used in tonsillectomy.

Image reference: Wikimedia commons website.

choices.text: It lies between the buccopharyngeal fascia anteriorly and Alar fascia posteriorly
It is the smallest space of pharynx but most commonly infected space
The abscess in these space presents as a unilateral paramedian bulge of the posterior pharyngeal wall
The space is divided in the midline into two lateral spaces called space of gillete

questions.text: Picture given below shows the Retropharyngeal space. Which of the following statements about Retropharyngeal space is not true?
questions.solution:
Smallest space of pharynx and the most commonly infected space of pharynx is the parapharyngeal space and not retropharyngeal space. ( Option B )

Retropharyngeal space lies just behind the wall of pharynx. It lies between the buccopharyngeal fascia anteriorly and Alar fascia posteriorly. ( Option A )

It starts superiorly at the base of skull and ends inferiorly at the bifurcation of trachea.

The space is divided in the midline by a raphe into two lateral space called space of Gillette. ( Option D ) They contain lymph nodes known as lymph nodes of rouviere.

The abscess in these space presents as a unilateral paramedian bulge of the posterior pharyngeal wall on one side. ( Option C )

Key Takeaway:

Retropharyngeal abscess: Inflammation of nodes of Rouvier → O/E: U/l bulge of posterior pharyngeal wall dt space divided by Raphe into Space of Gillette.

Image reference: Meddists website.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient known case of carcinoma lower lip. Picture given below. He was undertaken for wide local excision with neck dissection. The defect arising in the lower lip after surgery is more than 2/3 rd of the length of the lip. What should be the appropriate intervention for reconstruction in this case?
questions.solution:
Abbe flap is based on the main artery of the orbicularis Oris, the Labial artery. A portion of uninvolved lip is rotated across the mouth and placed into the surgical defect of the involved lip.

After 10 to 14 days, the flap is divided. The defect of the uninvolved lip from which the flap has been taken is sutured primarily.

Gillies fan flap borrow tissue from the cheek and adjacent sites.

Key Takeaway:

Lip Carcinoma management -

Image reference: Research gate journal

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presented with midline neck swelling since 4 months. USG local part is suggestive of nodule in the left lobe of thyroid gland. Hemi thyroidectomy was done in this patient. Postoperative histopathology report was suggestive of cells with salt and pepper chromatin arranged in sheets, nests or trabeculae in an organoid fashion. Cells were positive of calcitonin, CEA, chromogranin, and synaptophysin. Histopathology picture is given below. What is the type of thyroid neoplasm is seen here?
questions.solution:
Medullary carcinoma thyroid is a malignant tumour showing C cell differentiation. It constitutes 5 to 10 % of all thyroid malignancy.

Histologically it shows cells with salt and pepper chromatin arranged in sheets, nests or trabeculae in an organoid fashion.

Necrotic is infrequent. C cell hyperplasia can be seen in surrounding thyroid tissue adjacent to the invasive tumour. Cells are positive for calcitonin , chromagranin, CEA, synaptophysin. Amyloid deposits are also seen.

Option A: Papillary carcinoma shows cells arranged in monolayer papillae with characteristic nuclear features such as orphan Annie nuclei. It shows metaplasia squamous cytoplasm.

Option B: Follicular carcinoma shows cells arranged in follicles, solid or trabecular fashion. They lack the typical nuclear features.

Option D: Anaplastic carcinoma have pleomorphic large cells with high nuclear to cytoplasm Ratio.

Key Takeaway:

Medullary thyroid Carcinoma:

  • Salt & Pepper Chromatin & Amyloid Deposits
  • Synaptophysin & Chromogranin Positive.

Image reference: Pathology outlines website.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient known case of parathyroid carcinoma. Her Ct scan shows Mass invading the surrounding soft tissue but not invading trachea, oesophagus and larynx. What is the T staging in this case?
questions.solution:
The differentiated system divides the parathyroid carcinoma into 4 classes of risk, based on typical TNM staging system.

Key Takeaway:

Parathyroid Carcinoma Stage

  1. Capsular Invasion
  2. Soft Tissue Invasion
  3. Vascular Invasion
  4. Mediastinal Visceral Organs.

choices.text: No need for any calcium supplementation
500mg calcium tablet to be given orally three times a day
1 gram calcium tablet to be given orally three times a day along with 0.25microgram of calcitriol three times a day
Intravenous calcium plus 1gm calcium tab to be given three times a day along with calcitriol tablet

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient underwent Total thyroidectomy. Her postoperative serum calcium levels were measured. It was found to be 7.5mg/dl. What will be the most appropriate regimen of managing serum calcium level in this case?
questions.solution:
Key Takeaway:

Post operative calcium level below 7-8 mg/dl managed with 1 gram calcium tablet to be given orally three times a day along with 0.25microgram of calcitriol three times a day.

choices.text: Normal dose of 131 I used to ablation residual thyroid tissue is 100 to 140mCi
Patient is weaned off from iodine containing drugs and iodinated contrast procedures before ablation
It is mandatory to stop tablet thyroxine prior to imaging or therapy
Amount of residual thyroid calculation is ideally performed using thyroid uptake probe

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient known case of papillary carcinoma thyroid was advised radioiodine ablation after total thyroidectomy. All of the following statements about preparation of patient for radioiodine ablation are true except?
questions.solution:
The following are necessary to be done before radioiodine ablation or scan.

  1. Patient is weaned off form iodine containing drugs like cough suppressant and iodine contrast based imaging. ( Option B )
  2. Food stuff such as sea foods and iodinated salts should be avoided for 3 to 4 weeks.
  3. It is mandatory to stop tablet thyroxine so that serum thyroid level is elevated to more than 30 micro IU /ml. ( Option D )
  4. Amount of residual thyroid is calculated using thyroid uptake probe at 4, 6 and 24 hours after 20 micro curie 131 I application. ( Option D )
  5. Normal dosage of 131I used to ablation residual thyroid tissue is in the range of 30 to 70 mCi. ( Option A )
  6. Following ablation patient is put on suppressive doses of tablet thyroxine. A post therapy whole body scintigraphy is performed 5 to 7 days after ablation.

Key takeaway:

Normal dosage of 131I used to ablation residual thyroid tissue is in the range of 30 to 70 mCi.

questions.text: All of the following are the ultrasonography features of benign thyroid lesion except?
questions.solution:
Hypoechoic is finding seen in malignant lesions.

Key Takeaway:

Benign Thyroid Lesion

  • Hyperechoic due to purely Cystic
  • Peripheral vascularity
  • Spongiform appearance
  • Comet tail shadowing.

choices.text: Patient with multicentric, multifocal, and microscopic differentiated thyroid malignancy
Patient with I 131 concentrating in distant metastasis
All patients with follicular, papillary and mixed carcinoma of more than 1.5 cm in size with or without capsular invasion
Medullary carcinoma thyroid with capsular invasion

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient underwent hemi thyroidectomy, postoperative histopathology report suggested that the nodule was showing signs of carcinoma. She was advised to undergo radioiodine I131 ablation. All of the following are the indications for radioiodine ablation therapy except ?
questions.solution:
Selection of patient for radio iodine ablation:

  1. Patient with I 131 concentrating in distant metastasis. ( Option B )
  2. Patient with multicentric, multifocal, and microscopic differentiated thyroid malignancy. ( Option A )
  3. All patients with follicular, papillary and mixed carcinoma of more than 1.5 cm in size with or without capsular invasion. ( Option C )
  4. Patient with residual thyroid disease in which revision surgery is not possible.

Who should not be ablated:

  1. Patient with low risk factors including papillary carcinoma with tumor size 1 to 1.5 cm with no capsular invasion or distant metastasis.
  2. Patient with medullary carcinoma because they are based on parafollicular C cells which can't concentrate radioiodine. Hence, they are treated with 131 I labelled meta iodo benzyl guanidine (MIBG). ( Option D )

Key Takeaway:

Medullary carcinoma contains parafollicular C cells which cannot concentrate radioiodine. So Radioiodine ablation can't be done & Hence they are treated with 131 I labelled meta iodo benzyl guanidine (MIBG).
